summary: I keep seeing these posts like “Haha straightie Neil Gaiman accidentally made Good Omens gay” and I just,,, you FOOLS. You...
body: I keep seeing these posts like “Haha straightie Neil Gaiman accidentally made Good Omens gay” and I just,,, you FOOLS. You absolute FOOLS. You know who co-wrote Good Omens? Terry Pratchett. You really think that TERRY PRATCHETT, the author with an ONGOING TRANS STORYLINE in his books, and who wrote the brilliant leader of one of the main locations to be SO HEAVILY IMPLIED TO BE GAY IT’S RIDICULOUS.. you really think that he didn’t know exactly what he was doing while writing Good Omens?

tags: in which i get to discuss my favorite things
summary: Chapter Two is posted! They decided on the tourist traps for their next. “The London Eye,” Crowley declared, raising his arms...
caption:
Chapter Two is posted!

They decided on the tourist traps for their next.

“The London Eye,” Crowley declared, raising his arms triumphantly in front of it. “Isn’t she beautiful?”

Aziraphale struggled to come up with a suitable compliment. “It’s, erm, big. And—” he was unable to help himself, frowning at the swirls and eddies of people coming and going— “Crowded.”

Rated E | 5371 words | Chapter 2/6

summary: Also published on my Ao3.   Chubby It takes Crowley a few millennia to admit it to himself, but once he has, he can’t stop...
body:
Also published on my Ao3.  

Chubby

It takes Crowley a few millennia to admit it to himself, but once he has, he can’t stop thinking it:  watching Aziraphale’s mortal corporation grow chubby as the decades slide by is diverting.

At first, he puts it down to Adversarial caution.  It would be a daft demon who ignored their natural enemy’s weaknesses, after all.  Best to always be on one’s toes, always looking for a chink in their armor, et cetera.  It’s covert observation.  A cousin to lurking, if you will.

The Nile had carved its way through Egypt since The Beginning, but the term denial is not just a river in Egypt had not yet been invented.  Crowley couldn’t fathom how deeply he was sunk in it.

The first time he notices, he’s just been knocked down after one of his and Aziraphale’s customary bouts.  Stalks of wheat crumple as he sprawls in the dirt, pain shooting through him in a dozen different places.  He struggles to rise, then stills as the point of Aziraphale’s blade kisses his throat.

“Woah,” Crowley stammers, raising his hands.  He is acutely aware of the hairsbreadth between the blade and his messy discorporation. “Easy there, angel.”

Aziraphale considers him for a moment of silence.  Then he sighs and lowers the blade.  “Crowley.  It’s been… how long has it been?”

“Decades,” Crowley says.  He sits up and miracles the dirt off his tunic.  “You look well.”

Aziraphale narrows his eyes.  Clearly he’s picked up on sarcasm in the last century, and is trying to unearth the hidden barb in Crowley’s words.  When he can’t find it, he sheaths the sword and holds out a hand.  “You’re losing your edge, Adversary.”

Crowley grabs the proffered hand, and really, he can’t help himself – the words are out before he can catch them.  “So are you.”

A frown.  “But I won.”

“So you did.”

Aziraphale releases his hand.  “If you’re trying to deceive me, it won’t work.  I know you, you old serpent.”

“So you do,” Crowley says, because all his tongue is capable of forming is iterations of the same bloody sentence.  His attention has been well and truly ensnared.  Something about Aziraphale is… different.  Softer.  The edges are smoothed down, the hollows filled in.  He is still perfect in the sense that all angels are perfect, but he is no longer perfectly bland. He looks… comfortable.

Crowley squashes a sudden urge to revert to his old shape, to slither up the angel’s arm and bask on the warm, pliant nape of his neck.  He crosses his arms, fingernails biting into woolen sleeves. “I see you’ve found a new sword.”

Aziraphale looks flustered before mustering a prim, purse-lipped mask.  “Yes, well.  After the, er, kerfuffle with the flaming sword, I had to have a… a little chat with Gabriel.”  He looks like he’s swallowed tea brewed in a waste pit.  “Anyway, they decided I was best suited to thwart your wiles, so.” He pats the hilt of his sword.  “Here I am.”

“And more of you than ever,” Crowley says.

“And what, pray tell, is that supposed to mean?”

“Nothing at all.  I’m only appreciating the corpulent corporation with which my Heavenly counterpart comports himself.”

“What—”

But Crowley, whose preoccupation with Aziraphale’s body is rapidly outstripping his wits, has had enough of banter.  Their Adversarial enmity has long since faded into something blurred, wet ink on parchment – something you must squint at to read.  Nevertheless, Crowley doesn’t like taking chances.  You can never be sure who’s watching, and besides, best to keep the angel on his toes.

Crowley miracles a thin, dark blade into his hand and swings it at Aziraphale, leaving plenty of time for the angel to draw his sword and block.  They don’t speak much after that.

As the decades slide into centuries, Crowley keeps an eye on the angel’s changing form.  A cozy layer of fat swathes the once-sculpted ridges of muscle.  The bronze gleam of Heaven’s light fades from his skin, replaced by the pallor of shadowy corners in ancient libraries.  Lean, strong fingers grow soft and plump.

And, because Crowley is a demon, it seems only natural to wile the angel into indulgence.  In Nod, he feeds Aziraphale dates and figs and once, daringly, the sweetest apple he can coax from the trees.  In Gomorrah, he plies the angel with fermented date palm cocktails sprinkled with nutmeg and crushed lemongrass.  In Paris in 1793, he watches in delight as Aziraphale mops up tomato sauce with chunks of baguette, leaving no crumb untouched.  In the back room of Aziraphale’s bookshop, he swallows down his Chateau Lafite and tries not to gawk as the angel licks a stray drop of wine from the rim of his glass.

After the world almost ends, the angel and the demon are sitting at their customary table in the Ritz.  Crowley has evicted the previous guests, more out of a force of habit than any desire to mess people about.  He hopes Adam Young understands.

Sitting across from Aziraphale, watching with the intent, unblinking focus of a serpent, Crowley thinks he is only just beginning to understand it: Aziraphale’s plump, partridge-soft body is much more than a mere diversion.  Crowley stares down at the untouched swirl of chocolate mousse before him.

“Angel.”

“Hmm?” Aziraphale blinks and lowers his spoonful of soufflé.  “My dear, what is it?”

Crowley dunks his spoon in the mousse.  He lifts the offering, eyebrows raised.

Aziraphale understands, of course.  You can’t spend six-thousand years with a person – an angel, a demon, anyone – without learning every corner of their mind, every chink in their armor.  Crowley could laugh at himself.

Instead, he can only watch, spellbound, as Aziraphale leans across the small space.  His hand shakes.  The angel licks his lips and smiles.
body_abstract:
Also published on my Ao3.  

Chubby

It takes Crowley a few millennia to admit it to himself, but once he has, he can’t stop thinking it:  watching Aziraphale’s mortal corporation grow chubby as the decades slide by is diverting.

But Crowley, whose preoccupation with Aziraphale’s body is rapidly outstripping his wits, has had enough of banter.  Their Adversarial enmity has long since faded into something blurred, wet ink on parchment – something you must squint at to read.  Nevertheless, Crowley doesn’t like taking chances.  You can never be sure who’s watching, and besides, best to keep the angel on his toes.

Crowley miracles a thin, dark blade into his hand and swings it at Aziraphale, leaving plenty of time for the angel to draw his sword and block.  They don’t speak much after that.

As the decades slide into centuries, Crowley keeps an eye on the angel’s changing form.  A cozy layer of fat swathes the once-sculpted ridges of muscle.  The bronze gleam of Heaven’s light fades from his skin, replaced by the pallor of shadowy corners in ancient libraries.  Lean, strong fingers grow soft and plump.

And, because Crowley is a demon, it seems only natural to wile the angel into indulgence.  In Nod, he feeds Aziraphale dates and figs and once, daringly, the sweetest apple he can coax from the trees.  In Gomorrah, he plies the angel with fermented date palm cocktails sprinkled with nutmeg and crushed lemongrass.  In Paris in 1793, he watches in delight as Aziraphale mops up tomato sauce with chunks of baguette, leaving no crumb untouched.  In the back room of Aziraphale’s bookshop, he swallows down his Chateau Lafite and tries not to gawk as the angel licks a stray drop of wine from the rim of his glass.

After the world almost ends, the angel and the demon are sitting at their customary table in the Ritz.  Crowley has evicted the previous guests, more out of a force of habit than any desire to mess people about.  He hopes Adam Young understands.

Sitting across from Aziraphale, watching with the intent, unblinking focus of a serpent, Crowley thinks he is only just beginning to understand it: Aziraphale’s plump, partridge-soft body is much more than a mere diversion.  Crowley stares down at the untouched swirl of chocolate mousse before him.

“Angel.”

“Hmm?” Aziraphale blinks and lowers his spoonful of soufflé.  “My dear, what is it?”

Crowley dunks his spoon in the mousse.  He lifts the offering, eyebrows raised.

Aziraphale understands, of course.  You can’t spend six-thousand years with a person – an angel, a demon, anyone – without learning every corner of their mind, every chink in their armor.  Crowley could laugh at himself.

Instead, he can only watch, spellbound, as Aziraphale leans across the small space.  His hand shakes.  The angel licks his lips and smiles.
trail.content:
Also published on my Ao3.  

Chubby

It takes Crowley a few millennia to admit it to himself, but once he has, he can’t stop thinking it:  watching Aziraphale’s mortal corporation grow chubby as the decades slide by is diverting.

At first, he puts it down to Adversarial caution.  It would be a daft demon who ignored their natural enemy’s weaknesses, after all.  Best to always be on one’s toes, always looking for a chink in their armor, et cetera.  It’s covert observation.  A cousin to lurking, if you will.

The Nile had carved its way through Egypt since The Beginning, but the term denial is not just a river in Egypt had not yet been invented.  Crowley couldn’t fathom how deeply he was sunk in it.

The first time he notices, he’s just been knocked down after one of his and Aziraphale’s customary bouts.  Stalks of wheat crumple as he sprawls in the dirt, pain shooting through him in a dozen different places.  He struggles to rise, then stills as the point of Aziraphale’s blade kisses his throat.

“Woah,” Crowley stammers, raising his hands.  He is acutely aware of the hairsbreadth between the blade and his messy discorporation. “Easy there, angel.”

Aziraphale considers him for a moment of silence.  Then he sighs and lowers the blade.  “Crowley.  It’s been… how long has it been?”

“Decades,” Crowley says.  He sits up and miracles the dirt off his tunic.  “You look well.”

Aziraphale narrows his eyes.  Clearly he’s picked up on sarcasm in the last century, and is trying to unearth the hidden barb in Crowley’s words.  When he can’t find it, he sheaths the sword and holds out a hand.  “You’re losing your edge, Adversary.”

Crowley grabs the proffered hand, and really, he can’t help himself – the words are out before he can catch them.  “So are you.”

A frown.  “But I won.”

“So you did.”

Aziraphale releases his hand.  “If you’re trying to deceive me, it won’t work.  I know you, you old serpent.”

“So you do,” Crowley says, because all his tongue is capable of forming is iterations of the same bloody sentence.  His attention has been well and truly ensnared.  Something about Aziraphale is… different.  Softer.  The edges are smoothed down, the hollows filled in.  He is still perfect in the sense that all angels are perfect, but he is no longer perfectly bland. He looks… comfortable.

Crowley squashes a sudden urge to revert to his old shape, to slither up the angel’s arm and bask on the warm, pliant nape of his neck.  He crosses his arms, fingernails biting into woolen sleeves. “I see you’ve found a new sword.”

Aziraphale looks flustered before mustering a prim, purse-lipped mask.  “Yes, well.  After the, er, kerfuffle with the flaming sword, I had to have a… a little chat with Gabriel.”  He looks like he’s swallowed tea brewed in a waste pit.  “Anyway, they decided I was best suited to thwart your wiles, so.” He pats the hilt of his sword.  “Here I am.”

“And more of you than ever,” Crowley says.

“And what, pray tell, is that supposed to mean?”

“Nothing at all.  I’m only appreciating the corpulent corporation with which my Heavenly counterpart comports himself.”

“What—”

But Crowley, whose preoccupation with Aziraphale’s body is rapidly outstripping his wits, has had enough of banter.  Their Adversarial enmity has long since faded into something blurred, wet ink on parchment – something you must squint at to read.  Nevertheless, Crowley doesn’t like taking chances.  You can never be sure who’s watching, and besides, best to keep the angel on his toes.

Crowley miracles a thin, dark blade into his hand and swings it at Aziraphale, leaving plenty of time for the angel to draw his sword and block.  They don’t speak much after that.

As the decades slide into centuries, Crowley keeps an eye on the angel’s changing form.  A cozy layer of fat swathes the once-sculpted ridges of muscle.  The bronze gleam of Heaven’s light fades from his skin, replaced by the pallor of shadowy corners in ancient libraries.  Lean, strong fingers grow soft and plump.

And, because Crowley is a demon, it seems only natural to wile the angel into indulgence.  In Nod, he feeds Aziraphale dates and figs and once, daringly, the sweetest apple he can coax from the trees.  In Gomorrah, he plies the angel with fermented date palm cocktails sprinkled with nutmeg and crushed lemongrass.  In Paris in 1793, he watches in delight as Aziraphale mops up tomato sauce with chunks of baguette, leaving no crumb untouched.  In the back room of Aziraphale’s bookshop, he swallows down his Chateau Lafite and tries not to gawk as the angel licks a stray drop of wine from the rim of his glass.

After the world almost ends, the angel and the demon are sitting at their customary table in the Ritz.  Crowley has evicted the previous guests, more out of a force of habit than any desire to mess people about.  He hopes Adam Young understands.

Sitting across from Aziraphale, watching with the intent, unblinking focus of a serpent, Crowley thinks he is only just beginning to understand it: Aziraphale’s plump, partridge-soft body is much more than a mere diversion.  Crowley stares down at the untouched swirl of chocolate mousse before him.

“Angel.”

“Hmm?” Aziraphale blinks and lowers his spoonful of soufflé.  “My dear, what is it?”

Crowley dunks his spoon in the mousse.  He lifts the offering, eyebrows raised.

Aziraphale understands, of course.  You can’t spend six-thousand years with a person – an angel, a demon, anyone – without learning every corner of their mind, every chink in their armor.  Crowley could laugh at himself.

Instead, he can only watch, spellbound, as Aziraphale leans across the small space.  His hand shakes.  The angel licks his lips and smiles.

Also published on my Ao3.  

Chubby

It takes Crowley a few millennia to admit it to himself, but once he has, he can’t stop thinking it:  watching Aziraphale’s mortal corporation grow chubby as the decades slide by is diverting.

summary:
SPOILER FOR THE SHOW (kind of)
So remember THE scene in the GO Trailer that everyone pointed at (because it is super gay and...
body:
SPOILER FOR THE SHOW (kind of)

So remember THE scene in the GO Trailer that everyone pointed at (because it is super gay and therefore beautiful)? Well, here is the conclusion. It is fine I guess, not my wish but I didn’t really expect them to kiss and we see from the reaction of the nun that we weren’t wrong, when pointing out that it looked suspicious.

So yes, fine but not a wish come true, however, I hope you learned something.

summary:
Consider
the following sequel... Apocalypse-that-did-not-happen
was the turning point for both Crowley and Aziraphale. It made...
body:
Consider the following sequel…

Apocalypse-that-did-not-happen was the turning point for both Crowley and Aziraphale. It made them realize they were something more than enemies and so much more than just friends and so they started dating awkwardly shortly after the-not-end-days.

But, obviously, however forgiving appeared to be their respective head offices, none of them would accept angel-demon romance. That one thing seemed to be sure. They actually couldn’t even be friends legally, let alone lovers! Therefore Crowley and Aziraphale decided to do everything in their power to keep their relationship secret. And so they did…

Angel and demon were really proud of the many skillful strategies they invented to make their romance undetectable. They kept raising glasses to themselves all the time on that, congratulating one another, until both of them were too drunk to continue.

Crowley and Aziraphale wholeheartedly believed they managed to keep their love affair to themselves so, of course, everyone knew about it, even most insignificant creatures in Heaven and Hell.

Gabriel and Beelzebub were fairly disgusted. Oh, so disgusted! And furious, too! Mostly because… Well… Apparently… there was literally no rule to ban romances between angels and demons and not a single one to ban friendship between their kinds, too! Who would actually need them? I mean… SERIOUSLY? Who would want to befriend (ugh!) or DATE (sic!) a demon/an angel?! Unthinkable!

And thus Gabriel and Beelzebub ended up meeting to talk over the abominable relationship and how unthinkable, embarassing, nearly ineffably so, it was.

Could they invent some new laws, maybe? Should Gabriel ask God first? Would inventing new rules affect the whole the Arrangement thing? Wait! Would inventing new laws mean that they, Gabriel and Beelzebub, heve to… have to admit out loud that their subordinates were… MAKING OUT?! Such shame for both of them! Oh, such shame! 

And so it went on… 

After a century or so Gabriel and Beelzebub were SECRETLY dating so, of course, everyone, every single unimportant angel and tiny demon knew about it. Except maybe Aziraphale and Crowley… What about those two, you may ask?

They were together all the same and kept raising glasses to themselves, endlessly congratulating one another on their craft, until both of them were too drunk to continue.
